awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: An Analysis Tool Supporting the Safe Deployment of New Features in Evolving Software Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project will develop a tool-supported environment designed to aid in the safety analysis of software intensive systems. Developing highly dependable software for medical infusion pumps, positive train controls, and robotics applications is a challenging process that requires rigorous and systematic hazard analysis. Such systems are traditionally developed within a carefully controlled process that emphasizes detailed planning, upfront design, and phase-based quality assurance gateways. Despite these efforts, products are recalled for life-threatening safety vulnerabilities. The challenges of developing safety systems have led to the phenomenon known as the "big freeze" in which the cost, effort, and risk of introducing new features inhibit product evolution. The proposed solution will aid software safety analysts and other stakeholders in identifying system-level changes while simultaneously building a safety-case for certification or internal audit purposes. These abilities enable an organization to evolve their products without sacrificing safety, security, or other critical concerns, thereby increasing their competitive advantage. The project trains a diverse cadre of women, minorities, and persons with disabilities in entrepreneurial activities. 

This project will utilize cutting-edge, deep learning technologies to train a domain-specific language model that will be used to automatically generate and evolve accurate trace links between artifacts such as requirements, design, code, and test cases.  The generated trace links will be used to generate novel visualizations of hazards and their mitigation pathways (i.e., hazard slices), and to highlight changes that have been introduced across different versions of the system.  In addition, the hazard-slices will be integrated into existing safety-analysis techniques such as fault-trees and safety-assurance cases.  The novel hazard-based visualizations are designed to aid analysts and developers in addressing emergent safety concerns in large, complex, and evolving software projects. Finally, the work will provide tools for analyzing changes in the software system, generating explanations to aid in the identification of potential safety problems, and recommending actions that could be taken to mitigate safety risks introduced by the changes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this Partnerships for Innovation (PFI) project was to transform SAFA technology, developed under previous NSF grants,  into a viable commercial product. It focused on overcoming three significant technical challenges. These included developing highly accurate automated traceability utilizing deep-learning techniques, creating scalable artifact visualization for diverse projects, supporting safety analysis in evolving software projects with compliance to standards, and integrating these features into a professional, user-friendly, scalable, and high-performance tool.

Throughout the project, significant strides were made in achieving these goals. The era of Large Language Models (LLMs) significantly influenced the project's direction, particularly in enhancing the accuracy of generated trace links. A pilot study for a robotics company showcased the high accuracy of domain-specific trace link generation, marking a key achievement in this area. The SAFA tool was also equipped with advanced features like zoom, subtree focus, and robust search functionalities, addressing the challenge of scalable artifact visualization.

In the realm of safety analysis, the project's focus shifted slightly after engaging with pilot customers. Instead of fully integrating safety models into SAFA, the team redirected efforts towards supporting safety-related trace queries, allowing SAFA to assist in generating trace links and documentation pertinent to safety, without directly modeling the safety cases. This pivot responded to customer feedback indicating a preference for using SAFA to understand code bases and requirements, rather than for direct integration into safety cases.

Another significant development was the transformation of SAFA into a professional tool, capable of conducting pilot studies with various industrial organizations. This achievement was supported by the development of a new feature for dynamically generating hierarchical documentation from source code, enhancing SAFA's appeal and utility for organizations without rigorous requirements processes.

Key to the project's success was the development of pilot customer relationships, which included proof-of-concept pilots with eight commercial companies.  These pilot studies encompassed a range of applications, from onboarding and hand-over for IT consultants, managing enterprise-level software systems, to specific collaborations with Jet Propulsion Lab, where SAFA was applied to open requirements challenges.

In terms of professional development, the project offered substantial opportunities for training graduate and undergraduate students in commercialization of research products, and included participation in NSF’s I-Corp training and in Techstars global accelerator. The formation of SAFA.AI, inc, marked a significant step in commercialization. Defined as a B2B Software-as-a-Service company, SAFA.AI leverages natural language processing and deep learning to enhance software analysis in industries like automotive and robotics. The company's focus on using Large Language Models for automating traceability and document generation aligns with the evolving needs of software teams.

In conclusion, the project has not only met its initial objectives but also adapted to new industry needs, leading to innovative features in SAFA and successful pilot studies. The team's efforts in engaging with both academic and industrial communities, combined with strategic patenting and company formation, highlight the project's extensive impact on technology transfer and its potential for continued growth and application in the software development sector.


Last Modified: 01/01/2024
Modified by: Jane L Huang

    SAFA.AI
    Copyrighted
    Jane L Huang
    Requirements Generation
  • SAFA's delta view shows changes for one hazard tree across two versions of a software system. Changes are represented using color: new (green), removed (red), and modified (blue). Informational nodes are generated automatically and provide recommendations and information to help users assess safety
    Jane Cleland-Huang
    Copyrighted
    Jane L Huang
    SAFA Delta View
